The PSD2 compliant STET API’s of The Bank enable PSD2 Certified Third Parties to seamlessly connect with our AISP and PISP features. We warmly invite the general Fintech public to dive into our STET API’s as well!

Two-factor authentication adds an extra layer of security to your account. In addition to your username and password, you’ll need to enter a code that we will send to you via an app on your phone.
Your account has Two-factor Authentication currently enabled and disabling it will mean your account will only need a regular username and password to authenticate.
Use an application on your phone to get two-factor authentication codes when prompted.
Scan this barcode with your app
Scan the image above with the two-factor authentication app on your phone.
Enter the six-digit code from the application
After scanning the barcode image, the app will display a six-digit code that you can enter below.
Open your authentication app and retrieve the code for The Bank Openbank Portal.
You will receive an SMS containing a 6-digit code. Please provide this code below:
If you don't receive an SMS in the next seconds, re-send it again.

With our Bank Payment Initiation API you can allow customers and users to connect to their account and initiate a payment. Our Payment Initiation API will enable secure access to and payment initiation from Belgian Bank payment accounts

By finding out useful information about a customer’s transactions, you get a clear picture of their spending and earning habits. This enables you to approve contracts and purchases quickly, or give customers useful financial breakdowns.
Analyse a customer’s spending and earning patterns to help them to make smarter purchasing decisions. You can also connect customers with providers relevant to their lifestyle and interests.
CustomerInsights checks personal information such as the customer’s phone number, email address, birthdate, and many more.
Accounts gives you a holistic overview of customers account activities over the last 12 months.

Access useful information such as IBAN, BIC and the current account balance of your customer quickly and easily. You can also gain insight into customers’ transaction data, including amounts, dates, counterparties and much more.

With our Bank Payment Initiation API you can allow customers and users to connect to their account and initiate a payment. Our Payment Initiation API will enable secure access to and payment initiation from Belgian Bank payment accounts

How to create your developer account

Creating an account is simple and fast. In the header menu, you will find the Registration button, click on it and enter all the required fields. When typing in your phone number, make sure to include the international code of your country.
During the last step of your registration process, you will be asked to configure your SMS Two Factor Authentication flow to add extra security to your account.

After submitting your registration, you will receive a confirmation email with a link to activate your account. After activating your account, you will need to wait for our team members to validate your account and give you full access to all the features of the OpenBank Portal.
In order to be able to start using the OpenBank Portal, you need to create your first app.
Log in to the OpenBank Portal
Navigate to your Developer Dashboard and then go to Apps
Fill in all the mandatory fields (App name and redirect URI)
Your Application will now be shown, along with any other applications you have created, in the Apps section.
When you create an app, Client ID and Client Secret Key are automatically generated for you. You will need them to make calls from your application to the Sandbox endpoints.
Your Client ID and Client Secret Key can be found by going to the Apps. Simply select the app you created and scroll down to the access details section.

The API references is a detailed list of scopes, API endpoints and versions. This enables you to quickly search and see all the information necessary regarding a call, as well as parameters and response samples.
In the menu above you can download the full OpenAPI specifications in their Swagger file, to do it click the tab API References.

Two-factor authentication or 2FA, is an extra layer of security used when logging into websites or apps. With 2FA, you have to log in to your account using your username and password, also providing another form of authentication that only you know or have access to.
The Bank supports two different forms or 2FA, the SMS and TOTP application flows. The SMS is the default 2FA option for the OpenBank Portal.

For the Bank the default second form of authentication is SMS that is sent to the user’s phone number provided during the registration process. The Bank generates an authentication code, every time someone tries to sign in to your account. The only way someone else than you can log in to your account is if they have both your password and authentication code from your phone.
After signing up using the default 2FA method which is SMS,  if you want, you can change it in your Profile settings to the Authorisation App Flow.
TOTP (Time-based One Time Password) application automatically generates an authentication code that changes after a specific period of time.
Since SMS is the default 2FA method, if you prefer to use TOTP instead, navigate to your Profile page, under the Security section, update the 2FA method to the “Authorisation App”.
The first step is downloading Google Authenticator. This application will be the one responsible for generating valid access codes to complete your authentication flow.
After changing the 2FA method in your profile page, as mentioned before, a QR code will be automatically generated.
Using the Google Authenticator app you can add an entry and scan the QR code. After scanning, the app will display a six-digit code that you can enter in the input field next to the QR code.
From this point, every time you need to authenticate yourself, you will be prompted for a valid six-digit code. Just go back to Google Authenticator and input the latest self-generated code.

When you configure two-factor authentication, we will generate a whole set of your 2FA recovery codes. If you ever lose access to your phone, you can still authenticate using your recovery codes. You can always visualise these through your Profile page.
To keep your account secure, don't share or distribute your recovery codes. We recommend saving them with a secure password manager, such as:

The OpenBank Portal gives you the opportunity to test and validate your integrations in a safe environment, through our customised Sandbox. You can generate and visualise data, which is shared throughout your whole organisation.
To get access to your own private Sandbox, you need to request access to it.
When you request Sandbox access, one of our team members will review your application before granting the access. In order to do that, navigate to API products menu and then to Subscriptions.
Here you can view the available APIs, to which you have subscribed and the status of said subscriptions.
Find out all about our API’s specifications.
Our external resources are hosted on Github® and are all considered for public use, unless stated otherwise.
Please use the form on the left to ask us anything or provide your feedback. Our team will come back to you as soon as possible.
In order to report a connection incident, we need to know who you are. Your input is important to us, please log in or register to proceed.
We have a dedicated documentation section on the portal.
The request failed! Please try again.
Put these in a safe spot. If you lose your device and don't have the recovery codes you will lose access to your account.

Terms of use of the Bank Open Banking Portal
Please read these terms and conditions relating to the use of the Open Banking Portal website (hereinafter “the Portal”) carefully.

BY ACCESSING, VISITING OR USING THIS PORTAL, YOU, PERSONALLY AND/OR ON BEHALF OF THE LEGAL ENTITY OF WHICH YOU ARE A REPRESENTATIVE, AN AGENT OR AN EMPLOYEE WHEN ACTING IN SUCH CAPACITY, AGREE TO BE BOUND BY THE FOLLOWING TERMS OF USE (HEREINAFTER, “THE TERMS”), WHICH YOU EXPRESSLY ACCEPT. THESE TERMS ARE SUBJECT TO CHANGE. IF YOU DO NOT AGREE WITH THESE TERMS AS AMENDED FROM TIME TO TIME, PLEASE DO NOT ACCESS, VISIT OR MAKE ANY USE OF THIS PORTAL OR OF THE INFORMATION INCLUDED THEREIN.

The term "Portal" means this Open Banking Portal website as published from time to time at its own discretion by Bank SA/NV (see point 4. Editor, for more information), hereinafter the "Bank", and/or its related companies or companies in the group to which the Bank belongs, as well as all information, data, materials, tools, applications, API and (test) environments contained on the Portal (hereinafter “the Bank Content”).

This Portal and the Bank Content may be used, subject to these Terms, in relation to the creation of applications (to be) connected to the Bank environments and for testing purposes of such applications and their functionalities in a testing environment made available on the Portal and called “Sandbox”. The Sandbox do not contain, and may not be uploaded with, any real or client (personal) data. The Bank shall provide mock data that may be used in the Sandbox.

Certain sections or pages of the Portal may contain separate and/or additional terms and conditions, which supplement these Terms. In the event of a contradiction, the separate and/or supplementary terms and conditions shall prevail over these Terms for those sections or pages of the Portal to which they relate.

When accessing, visiting or using this Portal, you must satisfy yourself that the legal restrictions in effect in your own country duly allow you to access or use the Bank Content; otherwise, you should refrain from accessing, visiting and/or using the Portal accordingly.
In order to accessing, visiting or using the Portal, you must register on developer.bank.com.
When applying to go live with an application, you must also confirm that you satisfy the following conditions:

You are an authorized or registered third party payment service provider pursuant to the Belgian act of 11 March 2018 related to the status and control of the payment institutions and electronic money institutions, to the access to the activity of payment services, and the activity of issuing electronic money, and access to payment systems  (“PSD2 legislation”)  or any legal requirements in the country of your registered office implementing the Payment service directive (EU) 2015/2366; and
In case of cross-border provision of payment services, you benefit from the necessary European “passporting” authorization; Or
You prove, by entering the requested information or uploading the requested document, that you have formally applied for the relevant authorisations as described under i. and ii. above.

The Bank reserves the right to approve or reject your registration to the Portal, Sandbox and/or your application for going live with an application if you do not satisfy the abovementioned conditions.
You must ensure that any information that you provide in relation to your registration is complete and accurate and that it remains up-to-date for the term of your registration.
Upon successful registration on the Portal, you will be able to login with your username, chosen password and 2 factor authentication means.
Upon successful registration on the Sandbox, you will receive a Client ID (unique identifier for your registered app) and Client Secret (unique secret for your registered app).

For the purpose of these Terms, these user name, password, authentication means, Client ID and Client Secret shall be called “Credentials”. The Credentials are, and will remain, the property of the Bank. The Bank grants you a personal (non-transferable, non-assignable) license to use the Credentials for the sole purpose of accessing, visiting and using the Portal for your own personal use in accordance with these Terms.
You must keep the Credentials confidential and take all necessary measures to ensure that these Credentials will be kept secure.

If you become aware (or if you suspect) that the confidentiality, integrity or security of your Credentials have been compromised, you shall immediately inform the Bank upon becoming aware of such (suspicion of) breach of confidentiality, integrity or security.
3. Visit and use conditions of the Portal and Credentials
You are responsible for all activities that you engage when accessing, visiting or using the Portal and any activity that is engaged under your Credentials.

Any access, visit or use of the Portal under your Credentials must be in accordance with all documentation and requirements indicated on the Portal and/or made available by the Bank. You must comply with all legal requirements.
create any content that is unlawful or otherwise objectionable, or any content that may be construed as such, or that may harm the Bank’s reputation or the integrity of the financial system;

reverse compile, disassemble, reverse engineer and reconstruct any code of any software, data (including “test data” or “fake data” or “dummy data” or “mock data”), content or application present on the Portal;
modify, sell, rent, transfer, distribute, sublicense, or otherwise disclose or make available your Credentials to any other person than yourself and for any other purpose than the use of the Portal;

bypass any security mechanism or device used by the Bank in connection with the Portal, access the Portal on an unauthorized way or disrupt or negatively affect in any manner the functioning of the Portal, including by the introduction of any virus, malware or any kind of malicious software;
